s.text: The researcher who did Prusiner's lab work at the University of California at San Francisco quit over the publication of Prusiner's very first prion paper in 1982, arguing that Prusiner was overinterpreting the available data to push the prion hypothesis.

The researcher who did Prusiner's lab work at the University of California at San Francisco quit over the publication of Prusiner's very first prion paper in 1982, arguing that Prusiner was overinterpreting the available data to push the prion hypothesis.

Before moving on, a quick course in molecular biology: All living creatures, from viruses on up, pull off the feat of self-replication by encoding the necessary information in nucleic acids--in particular the double-stranded DNA discovered by Crick and Watson or, for a few renegade viruses, single-stranded RNA or even single-stranded DNA.
In particular, he had created mice with a genetic mutation that caused what was a normal protein--the prion protein, in Prusiner's lingo--to become abnormal and produce disease.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.
But there was still no paper proving the results to the scientific community.

This is what makes Prusiner's hypothesis so radical: Prions would be the only proteins on the planet that reproduce--not to mention infect and kill animals--and thus the only known exceptions to the rules of the Crick-Watson paradigm of molecular biology.
One reason a virus hasn't been found--if indeed a virus causes these diseases--is that no one is doing the laborious and expensive work to find it.
It's easy to imagine variations in viruses or bacteria, because they contain nucleic acids, which encode for variations.
